intro: Menodora integrifolia var. trifida, commonly known as the three-lobed moonflower, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It belongs to the family Apocynaceae, which includes many milkweed species, and is characterized by its showy, night-blooming flowers. The plant has compound leaves with three leaflets, and its stems are often covered in fine hairs. It produces small, cylindrical fruits that contain seeds with silky hairs, aiding in wind dispersal. The species is adapted to arid environments and is often found in rocky or sandy soils.
